author: Tanveer Mann
title: Shocking pictures show young cows crammed into cages at M&S dairy farm
text:
Calves up to six months old are being kept in small, solitary pens at a dairy farm that supplies milk to M&S (Picture: Animal Equality UK) An investigation has revealed how an M&S milk supplier keeps calves locked in small, solitary, pens for up to six months. 
This is the secret to making the tastiest almond milk at home Grange Dairy, in East Chaldon, Dorset houses around 1,000 calves, many of whom are up to six months old, in solitary pens despite animal welfare laws banning solitary housing for calves beyond eight weeks old.
The calves are used to rear cows that will go on to supply milk to leading supermarkets like Marks & Spencer.
The farm belongs to J F Cobb & Sons, which has been run by the Cobb family in Dorset since 1928. It is part of a group of farms that supplies 240,000 pints of milk to the high street every day.

Grange Dairy, in East Chaldon, Dorset houses around 1,000 calves (Picture: Animal Equality UK) Footage taken by the welfare group Animal Equality UK shows some of the larger calves barely being able to take a step forward or back.
They can be seen struggling to get into plastic hutches, designed to shelter them in poor weather, resulting in large open sores on their backs.
Dr Toni Shephard, Executive Director of Animal Equality UK, said: ‘Seeing row after row of baby calves alone in tiny pens — when they should naturally still be with their mothers — is truly heartbreaking.

She added: ‘UK animal welfare law recognises how vitally important exercise and social interaction is for calves and restricts solitary housing to just eight weeks, yet on this farm Animal Equality found female calves as old as six months cramped and suffering in individual pens.

We urge all supermarkets to implement a zero-tolerance policy when farms break animal welfare laws.’
Trading standards officers have reportedly confirmed the calves are older than eight weeks and have launched an investigation.
M&S have also sent in auditors following the ‘disappointing’ revelations.
The JF Cobb & Sons website reads: ‘All our energy is focused on keeping our cows comfortable and healthy.’
